title: 108_s684
content: The Act may be cited as the "Koby Mandell Act of 2003". Congress finds that numerous American citizens have been victims of terrorism worldwide, with over 100 murdered in attacks in Israel or territories administered by Israel or the Palestinian Authority. Some victims have not received equal services from the US Government compared to others harmed by terrorism overseas. The government has not adequately pursued terrorists who have harmed American citizens abroad. The Palestinian Authority has not advertised monetary rewards for capturing terrorists in their areas, where many terrorists involved in the murders of Americans are free and even hold official positions. Some public sites in these areas are named after terrorists who killed Americans. An office should be established within the Department of Justice to capture all terrorists who have harmed American citizens overseas and provide equal treatment for all American victims of overseas terrorism. Establishment of an Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism in the Department of Justice. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism within the Department of Justice administers the Rewards for Justice program, offering rewards to capture terrorists harming American citizens overseas, regardless of their origin or residence. Rewards are advertised in mass media and public sites. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism administers a program similar to the VINE system for notifying American victims of overseas terrorism or their immediate family. The program includes listing suspects' names and photographs on the website and organizations claiming responsibility for terrorist attacks. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism provides updates to victims or their families on efforts to capture terrorists, sends government representatives to attend funerals of American victims, submits reports to Congress, and collaborates with agencies to prevent murderers from profiting from their crimes. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism works to prevent terrorists who harm American citizens from profiting from books or movies about their crimes. They also identify terrorists serving in local police or security forces and request assistance be halted until further investigation. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism assesses patterns of prosecution of terrorists who harm American citizens overseas and monitors public actions by governments. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism monitors public actions by governments overseas related to terrorists who harm American citizens, and initiates negotiations for financial compensation for victims or their families. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism monitors the incarceration of terrorists who harmed Americans abroad to ensure their conditions are similar to those in the US. They also coordinate with other agencies to transfer released terrorists for further prosecution in the US. The Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism ensures that terrorists who have harmed Americans abroad are treated as persona non grata by the US government, including denying visas, refraining from political and diplomatic contacts, and advising against patronizing businesses owned by such individuals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2003 and beyond to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended.
